title: Avondale: A Local Geography Case Study
text: trying describe local, place-based characteristics, typical geographic unit interest neighborhood. Neighborhoods people live interact tend identities. However, neighborhoods always well-defined data products available directly neighborhood level. use Avondale neighborhood Cincinnati, Ohio examine potential issues working local geographies. Cincinnati, neighborhoods defined neighborhood community councils. However, definitions (Statistical Neighborhood Approximations) modified neighborhood boundaries align Census tract boundaries therefore commonly used research.

title: Avondale: A Local Geography Case Study
text: Census tracts often used approximate neighborhoods. common unit area defined U.S. Census Bureau, tracts relatively stable time average population 4,000 residents. Although based governmental neighborhood boundaries, tracts meant describe contextually similar areas. Hamilton County, 230 tracts 2000, 222 2010, 226 2020. Tracts can merged split every ten years Census Bureau, tract identifiers always unique. example, 2000 tracts 39061006700 39061003400 merged 2010, new tract given distinct identifier 39061027000. means Avondale comprised five vintage 2000 tracts, four vintage 2010 tracts. tracts make Avondale change 2010 2020.

title: Avondale: A Local Geography Case Study
text: ZIP codes corresponding Zip Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTAs) also used approximate neighborhood due accessibility. ZIP code component postal addresses available neighborhood /tract may . ZIP codes can also sometimes shared full addresses . However, ZCTA boundaries based postal routes rather contextual neighborhood characteristics, therefore always good neighborhood approximations. show Avondale aligns surrounding ZCTAs. 45229 ZCTA commonly used represent Avondale, includes North Avondale excludes Western, Eastern, Southern parts neighborhood. case, using ZCTA approximate neighborhood result underestimating percent population living poverty 7%.

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: Census tracts small statistical subdivisions county, average population 4,000 (max: 1,200; min: 8,000), redefined every 10 years. Census tracts often used level census geography precise American Community Survey data available.

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: map (2010 vintage) census tracts Hamilton County, Ohio colored relative estimated fraction households poverty. 2010-2019 222 census tracts Hamilton County, number 230 2000-2009 226 2020-2029.

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: Although census tracts approximate local neighborhoods, mostly based population size streets natural boundaries. Neighborhood boundaries can defined ways may appropriate context policy changes interventions. three different neighborhood definitions Cincinnati area. Cincinnati Community Council (CCC) Neighborhoods: Cincinnati Community Council neighborhood definitions neighborhoods within Cincinnati city limits Statistical Neighborhood Approximations (SNA) Neighborhoods: Created matching census tract boundaries Community Council boundaries closely possible Tract Boundary-Based Neighborhoods: Expansion neighborhood boundaries include neighborhoods within county

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: map (2010 vintage) tract boundary-based neighborhoods Hamilton County, Ohio colored relative estimated fraction households poverty.

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: Zone Improvement Plan (ZIP) codes often used place-based data matching mailing address doesn’t require geocoding spatial linkage; however, using ZIP codes can cause substantial scientific problems. ZIP codes continuously defined redefined time collections different streets US Postal Service. change frequently defined zonal boundaries, US Census Bureau developed ZIP code tabulation area (ZCTA) product way aggregate census data link ZIP codes. area ZCTAs ZIP codes varies widely representing 10,000 sq. mi. land area representing densely populated areas small 2 city blocks. population similarly variable average population 10,000 many ZIP codes representing less 1,000 even less 100 individuals. Unlike nearly census geographies, ZCTAs based population contextual neighborhood boundaries, rather location delivery post offices. Millions Americans currently use mailing address corresponds neighboring town, village, neighborhood receive mail , instead jurisdiction actually live. ZIP Codes always properly represent environment inhabitants, spatial analyses utilizing ZIP Codes misled place-based health researchers. One notable example recent Flint drinking water crisis, misalignment ZIP boundaries municipal boundaries City Flint, Michigan caused researchers public health officials initially conclude increased blood lead levels due drinking water contamination.

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: map (2010 vintage) ZCTAs Hamilton County, Ohio colored relative estimated fraction households poverty.

title: {cincy} Geographies
text: See vignette Avondale detailed case study impacts using different geographies estimate neighborhood-level characteristics. linked, interactive maps can used side--side investigation different {cincy} geography types vintages.

title: Spatial Interpolation
text: cincy::interpolate function allows user choose three sets weights used weighted sums /averages: block group population, block group number homes, block group area. Neighborhood  ZCTA  examples use population (pop) weights, homes area weights can used changing weights argument.  Note lose variability interpolating smaller geography larger geography. especially noticeable interpolating tract ZCTA. Also note three weights yield similar results example. However, result using area weights varies slightly compared homes population. conclusion supported correlation interpolated fraction_poverty values using three sets weights. Neighborhood fraction_poverty interpolated tract using population, homes, area weights  ZCTA fraction_poverty interpolated tract using population, homes, area weights
code: d_neigh_pop <-    d_tract |>   cincy::interpolate(to = cincy::neigh_cchmc_2010, weights = "pop") |>   st_transform(3735) d_zcta_pop <-    d_tract |>   cincy::interpolate(to = cincy::zcta_tigris_2010, weights = "pop") |>   st_transform(3735)

what: Cincinnati Neighborhood, Tract, County, and ZIP Code Geographies
title: Cincinnati Neighborhood, Tract, County, and ZIP Code Geographies
text: cincy package contains simple feature geographic polygon files (sf objects) define Cincinnati Neighborhood, Tract, County, ZIP Code Geographies.

title: Cincinnati Neighborhood, Tract, County, and ZIP Code Geographies
Cincinnati Neighborhood, Tract, County, and ZIP Code Geographies
text: Data objects data.frames class sf named geography, source, optionally vintage: Use autocomplete functionality R prompt (e.g., typing cincy:: pressing TAB twice) find needed sf object, narrowing first based geography (tract, zcta, neigh, county), source, optionally vintage. Consult help file object information data within : explore data documentation online https://geomarker.io/cincy/reference

title: Cincinnati Neighborhood, Tract, County, and ZIP Code Geographies
text: Data returned simple features objects. example, get Cincinnati neighborhoods, defined recent version community council boundaries CAGIS: get Cincinnati ZIP Codes, defined Census Bureau ZIP Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTAs), 2000: Alternatively, get 2010 Counties Cincinnati’s 7-county catchment area:

what: Add neighborhood based on census tract — add_neighborhood
title: Add neighborhood based on census tract — add_neighborhood
text: function uses internal data objects, hamilton_tract_to_cincy_neighborhood_2010 hamilton_tract_to_cincy_neighborhood_2020, add neighborhood cincy::neigh_cchmc_2010 cincy::neigh_cchmc_2020 row data frame.

title: Add neighborhood based on census tract — add_neighborhood
Add neighborhood based on census tract — add_neighborhood
text: .x data frame containing census tract column named census_tract_id, census_tract_id_2010, census_tract_id_2020 vintage string specifying use 2010 2020 census tract neighborhood lookup table; set override vintage found census tract id column names

title: Add neighborhood based on census tract — add_neighborhood
text: vintage tracts automatically inferred based name found tract column (census_tract_id_2010 census_tract_id_2020), can specified using vintage argument. just column census_tract_id exists, default 2010 used.

title: Add neighborhood based on census tract — add_neighborhood

title: Tidy eval helpers — tidyeval
text: page lists tidy eval tools reexported package rlang. learn using tidy eval scripts packages high level, see dplyr programming vignette ggplot2 packages vignette. Metaprogramming section Advanced R may also useful deeper dive. tidy eval operators {{, !!, !!! syntactic constructs specially interpreted tidy eval functions. mostly need {{, !! !!! advanced operators use simple cases. curly-curly operator {{ allows tunnel data-variables passed function arguments inside tidy eval functions. {{ designed individual arguments. pass multiple arguments contained dots, use ... normal way.   enquo() enquos() delay execution one several function arguments. former returns single expression, latter returns list expressions. defused, expressions longer evaluate . must injected back evaluation context !! (single expression) !!! (list expressions).   simple case, code equivalent usage {{ ... . Defusing enquo() enquos() needed complex cases, instance need inspect modify expressions way. .data pronoun object represents current slice data. variable name string, use .data pronoun subset variable [[.   Another tidy eval operator :=. makes possible use glue curly-curly syntax LHS =. technical reasons, R language support complex expressions left =, use := workaround.   Many tidy eval functions like dplyr::mutate() dplyr::summarise() give automatic name unnamed inputs. need create sort automatic names , use as_label(). instance, glue-tunnelling syntax can reproduced manually :   Expressions defused enquo() (tunnelled {{) need simple column names, can arbitrarily complex. as_label() handles cases gracefully. code assumes simple column name, use as_name() instead. safer throws error input name expected.
code: my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   data %>%     group_by(...) %>%     summarise(mean = mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, ...) {   # Defuse   var <- enquo(var)   dots <- enquos(...)    # Inject   data %>%     group_by(!!!dots) %>%     summarise(mean = mean(!!var)) } my_var <- "disp" mtcars %>% summarise(mean = mean(.data[[my_var]])) my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   # Use `{{` to tunnel function arguments and the usual glue   # operator `{` to interpolate plain strings.   data %>%     summarise("{{ var }}_mean_{suffix}" := mean({{ var }})) } my_function <- function(data, var, suffix = "foo") {   var <- enquo(var)   prefix <- as_label(var)   data %>%     summarise("{prefix}_mean_{suffix}" := mean(!!var)) }
